Wow, this looks really cool Petar.  I thought it would be awhile
before we =
saw HyperNEAT and novelty search combined.  I ran it while I
was working on=
 other stuff for a bit over 50,000 evaluations, checking
in on it periodica=
lly.  The behavioral diversity was really
impressive: I got guys that were =
taking baby steps and guys that were
doing yoga poses (I swear one of them =
did "the chair"), although there
were still a good number of repeats, espec=
ially near the end (falling
onto theirs knees seemed pretty common).  No on=
e that I saw had a good
walking gait, but I guess it's possible that one co=
uld have when I
wasn't watching, perhaps we need an option to browse the ar=
chive. I'm
curious about a few things, if you wouldn't mind sharing:

-What=
 did you use as a novelty metric?  It's seems like there are a
number of vi=
able options here.

-What do the nodes on the substrate mean, and are they =
just on a flat
plane?  I used your older version when it was first released=
, and if I
remember right the two on the left are inputs and the stuff on t=
he
right is various joints, but I wanted to make sure.

-Similarly, what do=
 you use as the 5th input on the CPPN?

Thanks,
David D'Ambrosio
